introduction.p: In a previous chapter on simple harmonic motion we studied oscillations of one block attached to a spring about its equilibrium. Wave phenomena arises as a result of the coupling of vibratory motions of many parts of a system. To develop a feel for the consequences of coupling of vibrations, we will study a simple system consisting of two blocks of masses m_1 and m_2 that are connected by a spring and supported on the two sides by two other springs as shown in . In this section we will study this system analytically.

figure.caption: Two blocks coupled with each other by a spring and attached to fixed supports with additional springs. At equilibrium, the blocks are at points marked O_1 and O_2. The x-component of the displacements of the two blocks as measured from O_1 and O_2 are denoted by x_1 and x_2. Any change in x_1 affects the forces on block 2 and any change on x_2 affects the forces on block 1. We say that the motions of the blocks are coupled.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Analytic Solution
subsection.p: We will study the one-dimensional motion of the coupled masses analytically by choosing the x-axis to coincide with the line of the springs and the blocks as shown in . Let x_1 and x_2 be the displacements of the two blocks from their equilibrium positions. Note that x_1 and x_2 are not the x-coordinates of the blocks but rather the x-components of their displacements from the corresponding equilibrium positions.

Let k_{s1} be the spring constant of the spring connecting block m_1 to the left support, k_{s2} the spring constant of the spring connecting block m_2 to the right support, and k_c the spring constant of the spring coupling the two blocks as indicated in the figure.

The x-components of the equations of motion of the two blocks are
\amp m_1\frac{d^2x_1}{dt^2} = -k_{s1} x_1-k_c (x_1-x_2), \amp m_2\frac{d^2x_2}{dt^2} = -k_{s2} x_2+k_c (x_1-x_2).

Rather than solve these two equations for arbitrary values of the masses and constants, let us simplify the problem by looking at the case where masses are equal and two of the springs connecting the blocks to the support have equal spring constants.
\amp m_1 = m_2 \equiv m \amp k_{s1} = k_{s2}\equiv k_s > Then, the equations of motion for x_1 and x_2 are
\amp m\frac{d^2x_1}{dt^2} = -k_{s} x_1-k_c (x_1-x_2), \amp m\frac{d^2x_2}{dt^2} = -k_{s} x_2+k_c (x_1-x_2).
To solve these equations, I will introduce new composite variables X and x in place of x_1 and x_2 by
\amp X = \frac{x_1 + x_2}{2}, \amp x = x_1 - x_2.
Equations and then gives rise to the following equations of motion for X(t) and x(t).
\amp m\frac{d^2X}{dt^2} = -k_s X, \amp m\frac{d^2x}{dt^2} = -\left( k_s+2k_c \right) x.
Equation is an equation of motion of an oscillator of mass m and spring constant k_s, and Eq. is an equation of motion of an oscillator of mass m and spring constant k_s+2k_c. Therefore, we can think of X and x as displacements of two fictitious simple harmonic oscillators of mass m attached to springs of spring constants k_s and \left( k_s+2k_c \right) respectively. The solution of these equations show that the variables X and x will oscillate with angular frequencies given by
\amp \text{X oscillates at: }\ \ \ \omega_X = \sqrt{\frac{k_s}{m}} \amp \text{x oscillates at: }\ \ \ \omega_x = \sqrt{\frac{k_s+2k_c}{m}}
The variables X and x are called normal modes and the angular frequencies \omega_X and \omega_x the normal frequencies of this system of two masses. The normal coordinates X and x execute simple harmonic motions of their corresponding frequencies and are given by
\amp X(t) = A \cos(\omega_X t-\delta) \amp x(t) = B \cos(\omega_x t-\phi)
From Eqs. and , we see that x=0 when x_1=x_2, i.e., when the two blocks have equal displacment, the motion is that of mode X. When x_1=-x_2, i.e., ehen their displacments are opposite, X=0, in which case, the motion is in mode x. These are illustrated in .

figure.caption: Illustrations of the two normal modes X and x. In mode X, the blocks move in tandem, both towards right or both towards left, such that the middle spring in unaffected. In mode x, the blocks move in the opposite directions such that the center of mass of the two blocks remains fixed.
